text:
Madison Avenue, east side, at 121st Street, alongside of Mt. Morris Park, showing Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour. It was built in 1882-83 for the Congregational Church of Harlem, which simultaneously changed its name to The Pilgrim Church of New York, and occupied by them until 1917. For a brief period around 1920 this church was used by the Knights of Columbus.

July 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(1)
Mt. Morris Park, eastern side, view east, showing the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour (originally the Pilgrim Congregational Church), at Madison Avenue and 121st Street, in the background.

July 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, closer to the church.

July 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Mt. Morris Park, eastern side, view east, showing the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour (originally the Pilgrim Congregational Church), at Madison Avenue and 121st Street, in the background.

July 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, closer to the church.

July 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

Mt. Morris Park, south side (120th Street) view northeast, showing the old Pilgrim Church in the background. This church was originally built for the Congregationists of Harlem, but has lost its original congregation, and is, at the time of this picture, the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour.

July 25, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
